en_second_half: woman, he might have been made still more respectable than he was:—he might even have been made amiable himself; for he was very young when he married, and very fond of his wife. But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature of himself;—more narrow–minded and selfish.
en_results: woman, one who was more inclined to indulge in the softer feelings of the heart, he might have been a truly happy man. However, his wife, though a woman of considerable beauty, was not endowed with the qualities that would have made her a suitable companion for him. She
en_results_raw: woman, one who was more inclined to indulge in the softer feelings of the heart, he might have been a truly happy man. However, his wife, though a woman of considerable beauty, was not endowed with the qualities that would have made her a suitable companion for him. She was vain, selfish, and utterly lacking in the virtues that he valued most in a person. As a result, their marriage was a loveless and unfulfilling one, with both partners going through the motions of married life without any genuine affection or emotional connection. Despite this, he continued to conduct himself with propriety, never allowing his personal unhappiness to affect his professional demeanor. He was a man of great reserve, and his feelings were not easily discernible to those who did not know him well. His colleagues and acquaintances saw only the polished exterior, and they were none the wiser to the turmoil that lay beneath. In fact, he was so skilled at hiding his true emotions that even his wife was often unaware of the depth of his unhappiness, and she continued to treat him with the same cold indifference that she had always shown him. As the years went by, he became increasingly withdrawn, content to live a solitary life, free from the burdens of emotional attachment, but also devoid of the joys that came with it. His life was a dull and uneventful one, a mere existence, devoid of passion or purpose, a testament to the emptiness that had taken up residence in his heart.

Mrs. Dashwood, though she dreaded the removal, was anxious to be with her children, and to establish them in their new home; and, therefore, with a heart full of sorrow, she consented to leave Norland, and to remove to Barton, a place which, though it had been her husband's choice, she had never seen, and which, from the description of its situation, she feared would be disagreeable to her. The family, however, were all eager to be gone, and the day was fixed for their departure, which was to take place in a fortnight. In the meantime, Mrs. Dashwood was busily employed in making arrangements for the journey, and in preparing her children for the change which was approaching. She was anxious to make the best of it, and to render their removal as comfortable as possible, but she could not help feeling a pang of regret at leaving the only home they had ever known, and the friends they had made there. The children, however, were in high spirits, and were eagerly looking forward to the new scenes and adventures which awaited them in Devonshire. They were to travel in a carriage, and were to be accompanied by their mother, their aunt, and their maid, who was to be their governess as well as their attendant. The journey was to be a long one, but they were all in good health, and were looking forward to the pleasure of seeing new places and meeting new people. As the day of their departure drew near, Mrs. Dashwood's anxiety increased, and she found it difficult to sleep at night, thinking of all the changes that were to take place, and of the unknown future that lay before them. She was, however, determined to be brave, and to make the best of their new life in Devonshire, and to give her children the happiness and the advantages which she knew they deserved. With this resolution, she rose early on the morning of their departure, and began to make the final preparations for their journey. The carriage was to be at the door at ten o'clock, and she was determined to be ready, and to have everything in order, before it arrived. en_results_raw: His responses, though polite, were so brief and unenthusiastic that she found herself struggling to sustain the conversation, her attempts at humor and lightheartedness falling flat in the face of his unyielding reserve. She began to feel a growing sense of disappointment and frustration, wondering if she had misjudged him entirely, and if their acquaintance was doomed from the start. The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the sound of the clock ticking away on the mantle, its steady beat a reminder of the awkwardness that had settled over the room. Elinor's eyes wandered to the window, where the fading light of day cast long shadows across the floor, and she felt a pang of restlessness, a desire to escape the stifling atmosphere that had developed between them. She turned back to their visitor, determined to try once more to break the ice, but his expression remained impassive, a mask of politeness that hid any true emotion or interest. As the minutes ticked by, Elinor's efforts to engage him in conversation grew more desperate, her words spilling out in a nervous torrent as she struggled to find a topic that might spark some glimmer of connection, some sign that they were not as mismatched as she feared. But still he remained aloof, his responses as curt as ever, leaving Elinor to wonder if she was the only one who felt the weight of their awkwardness, or if he too was trapped in this prison of reserve, unable to escape the constraints of his own reserve. The silence between them grew thicker, a palpable thing that seemed to vibrate with tension, until finally, just when it seemed as though the conversation was about to collapse entirely, he spoke up, his voice low and measured, and Elinor's heart skipped a beat as she wondered what he might say next.

en_second_half: and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
en_results: and sometimes, I must confess, in a mistaken estimate of their feelings, which, however, I have generally found to be the result of my own want of observation, rather than any want of good intentions. I have often been struck by
en_results_raw: and sometimes, I must confess, in a mistaken estimate of their feelings, which, however, I have generally found to be the result of my own want of observation, rather than any want of good intentions. I have often been struck by the disparity between the impression I had formed of a person and the reality, and I have come to realize that it is a common failing to judge others by our own standards, rather than taking the time to truly understand them. It is a lesson I have learned the hard way, and one that I continue to work on to this day, as I navigate the complexities of relationships and social interactions. In fact, I have come to believe that it is the people who are the most confident in their own judgments who are often the most prone to error, and that humility and a willingness to learn are essential qualities for truly understanding others.

Pero, ¿quién puede igualar la descripción de Wordsworth cuando habla de la "gloria inmortal de las montañas, de los valles, de los ríos y de los lagos"? ¿Quién puede igualar la poesía de Coleridge cuando describe la "maravilla de la naturaleza, que se despliega ante nuestros ojos como un tapiz de colores y de formas infinitas"? La admiración por la naturaleza es algo que se ha vuelto demasiado común, demasiado fácil, y por eso, a menudo, se reduce a simples frases hechas y a descripciones vacías. Pero, para mí, la verdadera belleza de la naturaleza se encuentra en los detalles, en los pequeños momentos que pasamos desapercibidos, en la forma en que la luz se refleja en el agua, en la forma en que el viento susurra a través de los árboles, en la forma en que la tierra se curva y se ondula bajo nuestros pies. Es en esos momentos, en esos detalles, donde la naturaleza nos habla a nosotros de una manera que es única, que es auténtica, que es verdaderamente sublime. Y es allí donde la admiración por la naturaleza se convierte en algo más que una simple jerigonza, se convierte en una forma de conexión con algo más grande que nosotros mismos, con algo que nos hace sentir pequeños, pero a la vez, conectados a algo que es infinito y eterno.

La relación entre las Dashwood y los Ferrars era muy estrecha, y se sentían como una gran familia, y Sir John siempre estaba dispuesto a ayudarles en lo que necesitaran, ya que sabía que estaban pasando por un momento difícil en su vida.

It began on a stormy night, when I stumbled upon an old, mysterious mansion that seemed to appear out of nowhere. The wind howled and the trees creaked as I approached the entrance, and I felt an inexplicable pull, as if something was beckoning me inside. I pushed open the creaky door and stepped into the darkness, my heart racing with anticipation. The air inside was thick with the scent of decay and rot, and I could hear the faint whisper of footsteps echoing through the halls. I fumbled for my flashlight and turned it on, casting a weak beam of light into the darkness. The walls were adorned with cobweb-covered portraits, their subjects' eyes seeming to follow me as I moved. I felt a chill run down my spine as I realized that I was not alone in the mansion. Suddenly, a door slammed shut behind me, and I was plunged into total darkness. I was trapped, and I had no idea how to escape. The silence was oppressive, and I strained my ears to hear any sound, but there was nothing. And then, I heard it - a low, menacing whisper in my ear, "Welcome home." I spun around, but there was no one there. The whisper seemed to come from all around me, echoing off the walls. I tried to run, but my feet felt heavy, as if rooted to the spot. The whisper grew louder, more urgent, and I felt a presence closing in around me. I was paralyzed with fear, unable to move or speak. And then, everything went black.

Mi propósito... mi deseo, mi único deseo al querer eso... espero, creo que así es... es poder dar consuelo... no, no debo decir consuelo, no consuelo momentáneo,

Me duele ver a una mujer tan digna y noble en una situación tan desesperada, y quiero hacer todo lo que esté en mi poder para ayudarla. Me pregunto si podría visitarla y hablar con ella, para ver si puedo hacer algo para aliviar su sufrimiento. La señora Jennings me dijo que la señora Ferrars se encuentra en una situación muy delicada, y que necesita alguien que la escuche y la comprenda. en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."
en_results: output>completion>
en_results_raw: <output>completion>
vi_first_half: - Tư cách của anh giờ được đặt trước mặt cô - xa hoa, phóng đãng, và còn tệ hại hơn cả hai. Khi đã biết được tất cả - vì tôi đã biết được nhiều tuần rồi - cô thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì khi nhìn thấy em gái cô vẫn thân ái với anh ấy như bao giờ; và khi được tin em gái cô sẽ cưới anh ấy, thử đoán tôi đã nghĩ gì cho cô ấy. "Tuần rồi khi tôi đến đây và thấy cô chỉ có một mình, tôi đến với chủ định tìm hiểu sự thật; tuy không rõ mình sẽ làm gì một khi đã biết sự thật đau lòng. Lúc ấy cử chỉ của tôi hẳn là kỳ lạ đối với cô, nhưng bây giờ cô đã hiểu tại sao. Làm cho hai cô đau khổ thấy bị lừa dối như thế; thấy em gái cô... nhưng tôi làm gì được? Tôi không hy vọng ngăn cản được cuộc hôn nhân, và đôi lúc tôi nghĩ ảnh hưởng của em gái cô sẽ cảm hóa được anh ta." "Nhưng bây giờ, sau những sự lợi dụng ô nhục như thế, ai mà nói được anh toan tính những gì với em gái cô. Tuy nhiên, bất luận các toan tính này là như thế nào, khi em gái cô so sánh hoàn cảnh của mình với hoàn cảnh của Eliza khốn khổ của tôi, khi biết qua tình trạng cùng khổ vả vô vọng của con bé đáng thương này, bây giờ
vi_second_half: em gái cô hẳn cảm thấy - sau này chắc chắn sẽ cảm thấy - là hoàn cảnh của mình còn may mắn. Em gái cô nên tưởng tượng mình là con bé kia; với tình cảm dành cho anh ta còn sâu đậm - cũng sâu đậm như chính tình cảm của em cô - với tư tưởng giằng xé vì tự trách mình, và tư tưởng này cứ vương vấn suốt đời. Chắc chắn so sánh này sẽ hữu ích cho em gái cô. Cô ấy sẽ thấy những khổ sở của mình không là gì cả. Đây chỉ là do hành vi sai lạc, chứ không làm ô nhục. Trái lại, các khổ sở này phải khiến mỗi bằng hữu của em gái cô trở thành bạn tốt hơn. Mối quan tâm tới bất hạnh của em gái cô, và lòng kính trọng cho sự chịu đựng bất hạnh này, phải cũng cố mọi quan hệ gắn bó." "Tuy nhiên, cô nên suy xét khi truyền đạt đến cô ấy những gì tôi đã kể cho cô nghe. Hẳn cô là người biết rõ hơn ai hết ảnh hưởng là như thế nào; nhưng nếu tôi đã không tin một cách nghiêm túc từ trong thâm tâm rằng mình có thể giúp ích, có thể xoa dịu tiếc nuối của em gái cô, thì tôi đã không chịu khổ sở để làm phiền cô vì câu chuyện đau buồn này trong gia đình tôi - có vẻ như với mục đích đề cao tôi và hạ nhục người khác."

es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

es_results_raw: <output>completaré la historia de mi pobre Eliza, cuando ella, con su inocencia y su bondad, se vio arrastrada a una situación tan deshonrosa. Recuerdo el día en que la conocí, con su sonrisa radiante y su corazón lleno de esperanza. Era una joven de gran belleza, con un espíritu fuerte y una determinación que la llevaba a perseguir sus sueños. Pero, al igual que su hermana, también ella se vio atrapada en una red de engaños y manipulaciones, y su inocencia fue pisoteada por la codicia y la ambición de aquellos que la rodeaban. Su historia es una lección para todos nosotros, un recordatorio de la importancia de la honestidad y la integridad en nuestras vidas. Y ahora, al ver a su hermana en una situación similar, no puedo evitar pensar en la suerte que tuvo Eliza de escapar de aquella trampa, aunque a costa de su honor y su felicidad. Pero, ¿y si su hermana no tuviera la misma suerte? ¿Qué pasaría si ella también se viera atrapada en la misma red de engaños y manipulaciones? La idea me llena de angustia y me hace sentir impotente, incapaz de hacer nada para evitarlo. Sin embargo, sé que debo seguir adelante, que debo seguir buscando la verdad y la justicia, aunque sea a costa de enfrentarme a la adversidad y a la desaprobación de aquellos que me rodean. Porque, al final, es la verdad lo que importa, y es la verdad lo que me llevará a encontrar la paz y la satisfacción en mi corazón. Pero, ¿qué pasaría si su hermana ya no estuviera en peligro? ¿Qué pasaría si ella hubiera escapado de la trampa y estuviera a salvo? La idea me llena de alivio y me hace sentir un poco más tranquilo, pero también me hace reflexionar sobre la importancia de la vigilancia y la precaución en nuestras vidas. Debemos estar siempre atentos a los peligros que nos rodean, y no dejar que la complacencia y la confianza nos hagan caer en la trampa. Y ahora, al pensar en su hermana, me pregunto si ella ha aprendido la lección, si ha tomado medidas para protegerse a sí misma y a su familia de la codicia y la ambición de aquellos que la rodean. O si, por el contrario, sigue siendo vulnerable a los engaños y las manipulaciones, y si su situación empeorará con el tiempo. La incertidumbre me hace sentir inquieto y me hace desear saber la verdad, aunque sea difícil de escuchar. en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

Una simple muchacha pueblerina, desmañada, sin estilo ni elegancia, y casi sin ningún atractivo. La recuerdo perfectamente. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada. Me sentí muy decepcionada al enterarme de que mi hermano había decidido casarse con ella, y mi madre, que siempre había sido muy protectora conmigo, me advirtió que no debía decir nada, que no debía hacer nada que pudiera dañar la felicidad de mi hermano. Pero yo no podía evitar sentir una gran tristeza al pensar en la suerte que había echado mi hermano. ¿Qué había visto en ella que yo no había visto? ¿Qué había visto que la había hecho tan especial a los ojos de mi hermano? Me preguntaba a mí misma una y otra vez, sin encontrar respuesta. Mi madre me dijo que debía aceptar la decisión de mi hermano y que debía ser feliz por él, pero yo no podía evitar sentir una gran inquietud en mi corazón. ¿Qué iba a pasar con mi hermano? ¿Qué iba a pasar con su vida? Me sentí muy inquieta y decidí que debía hacer algo para descubrir la verdad. Así que empecé a investigar, a preguntar a los demás miembros de la familia y a los amigos de mi hermano, pero nadie parecía saber nada. Fue entonces cuando decidí visitar a mi tía, que siempre había sido muy cercana a mi hermano y que sabía más de lo que decía. Me dirigí a su casa, decidida a descubrir la verdad sobre la novia de mi hermano. Al llegar a su casa, me recibió con una sonrisa amable y me invitó a sentarme. Me preguntó qué la había llevado a su casa y le conté todo lo que había pasado. Mi tía me escuchó atentamente y cuando terminé de hablar, me miró con una expresión seria.
